div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [19--]
div1.p:
Malaria Mosquito Will Fly Against
8-Mile Breeze For Distance of
Two Miles and Across Mile of
Open Water, Dr. Byrd Claims

That the malaria mosquito or
Anopheles will fly against an eight-
mile breeze for a distance of two
miles across a mile of open water,
is the conclusion reached by Dr.
J. L. Byrd, Health Officer of Cris-
tobal - Colon, after extensive flight
observations at Manzanillo Island.
Data from a paper ready by Dr. Byrd
before the 198 meeting of the Med-
ical Association of the Canal Zone
at the Ancon Hospital May 18, on
the anti-malarial campaign at
Cristobal-Colon, was obtained Sat-
urday at Balboa Heights.

Dr. Byrd pointed out that Cris-
tobal-Colon once known as one of
the most unhealthy seaports in the
world, is situated on Manzanillo
Island, near the Atlantic entrance
to the Panama Canal.

The Island was once a tidal
swamp but has been largely filled.
In 1905 General Gorgas and his
co-workers eradicated yellow fever
from this area and by 1917 the
anti-malaria works had been extend
ed to about half a mile from the
inhabited section. This belt was
thoroughly sanitated, all vegetation
being kept closely trimmed, the
swampy areas were either filled or
drained and the drains oiled at re-
gular intervals of seven days. This
eliminated anopheles breeding from
Manzanillo Island and the adjoin-
ing part of Mount Hope District.
Nevertehless, malaria continued.

On investigation it was found
that countless numbers of anophe-
lines were being bred in the ex-
tensive swamps which surround the
city on three sides and during 1917.
1918 and 1919 appeared in such
quantities on the screens at Colon
Hospital and the Washington Hotel
at the beginning of the rainy sea-
son and for the following three
months that it was necessary to
detail a laborer to kill them with lar-
vacide applied with a knapsack
spray.

These mosquitoes came from the
swamps two miles distant across
Manzanillo Bay, a mile of open
water. Flight observations clearly
indicate that they would fly against
an eight mile breeze for a distance
of two miles. The drainage of these
swamps by sea-level canals in 1920-
21 did away with this annual vis-
itation of anophelines. Very little
oil was used in controlling mos-
quito breeding in the swamps in
question. Trochas (paths) six feet
wide were cut through the swamp
at intervals of 50 yards and- sea
level drains about eight inches wide
dug along their center. The drains
were kept free of vegetation. This
method was not expensive and has
proven very effective, malaria be-
ing successfully controlled and prac-
tically eradicated from Cristobal-
Colon.
